Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1963, a 21-year-old physicist 
named Stephen Hawking was diagnosed with a rare
neuromuscular disorder called amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, 
or ALS. Gradually, he lost the ability to walk, use his hands, move his face, and even swallow. But throughout it all,
he retained his incredible intellect, and in the more
than 50 years that followed, Hawking became one of history’s most 
accomplished and famous physicists. However, his condition went uncured and he passed away in 2018 
at the age of 76. Decades after his diagnosis, ALS still ranks as one 
of the most complex, mysterious, and devastating 
diseases to affect humankind. Also called motor neuron disease 
and Lou Gehrig’s Disease, ALS affects about two out of every
100,000 people worldwide. When a person has ALS, their motor neurons, the cells responsible for all voluntary 
muscle control in the body, lose function and die. No one knows exactly why
or how these cells die and that’s part of what 
makes ALS so hard to treat. In about 90% of cases, the disease arises suddenly, 
with no apparent cause. The remaining 10% of cases are hereditary, where a mother or father with ALS passes 
on a mutated gene to their child. The symptoms typically first appear 
after age 40. But in some rare cases, like Hawking’s,
ALS starts earlier in life. Hawking’s case was also a medical marvel 
because of how long he lived with ALS. After diagnosis, most people with 
the disease live between 2 to 5 years before ALS leads to respiratory problems 
that usually cause death. What wasn’t unusual in Hawking’s case
was that his ability to learn, think, and perceive with his senses 
remained intact. Most people with ALS do not experience
impaired cognition. With so much at stake 
for the 120,000 people who are diagnosed with ALS annually, curing the disease has become one of 
our most important scientific and medical challenges. Despite the many unknowns, we do have some insight into how ALS 
impacts the neuromuscular system. ALS affects two types of nerve cells 
called the upper and lower motor neurons. In a healthy body, 
the upper motor neurons, which sit in the brain’s cortex, transmit messages
from the brain to the lower motor neurons, situated in the spinal cord. Those neurons then transmit 
the message into muscle fibers, which contract or relax in response, resulting in motion. Every voluntary move we make occurs because of messages transmitted 
along this pathway. But when motor neurons degenerate in ALS, their ability to transfer 
messages is disrupted, and that vital signaling system 
is thrown into chaos. Without their regular cues, 
the muscles waste away. Precisely what makes 
the motor neurons degenerate is the prevailing 
mystery of ALS. In hereditary cases, parents pass genetic 
mutations on to their children. Even then, ALS involves multiple genes with multiple possible impacts 
on motor neurons, making the precise triggers
hard to pinpoint. When ALS arises sporadically,
the list of possible causes grows: toxins, viruses, lifestyle, or other environmental factors 
may all play roles. And because there are 
so many elements involved, there’s currently no single test that
can determine whether someone has ALS. Nevertheless, our hypotheses 
on the causes are developing. One prevailing idea is that certain
proteins inside the motor neurons aren’t folding correctly, and are instead forming clumps. The misfolded proteins and clumps 
may spread from cell to cell. This could be clogging up normal
cellular processes, like energy and protein production, 
which keep cells alive. We’ve also learned that along with 
motor neurons and muscle fibers, ALS could involve other
cell types. ALS patients typically have inflammation 
in their brains and spinal cords. Defective immune cells may also play 
a role in killing motor neurons. And ALS seems to change the
behavior of specific cells that provide support for neurons. These factors highlight 
the disease’s complexity, but they may also give us a fuller
understanding of how it works, opening up new avenues for treatment. And while that may be gradual,
we’re making progress all the time. We’re currently developing new drugs, new stem cell therapies 
to repair damaged cells, and new gene therapies 
to slow the advancement of the disease. With our growing arsenal of knowledge, we look forward to discoveries
that can change the future for people living with ALS.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is also called _______.
Options: A. Multiple sclerosis, B. Motor neuron disease, C. Lou Gehrig’s disease, D. Motor neuron disease and Lou Gehrig's disease
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the rare neuromuscular disorder that Stephen Hawking was diagnosed with in 1963, which is also known by two other names? Options: A. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), B. Motor Neuron Disease, C. Lou Gehrig's Disease, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 2: What is the primary function of motor neurons in the human body? Options: A. To control involuntary muscle movements, B. To regulate body temperature, C. To transmit messages for voluntary muscle control, D. To produce hormones Correct Option: C
Question 3: According to the transcript, what is the typical expected lifespan of a person diagnosed with ALS after the onset of symptoms? Options: A. 10-15 years, B. 2-5 years, C. 5-10 years, D. 1-2 years Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary difference between hereditary and sporadic cases of ALS? Options: A. Age of onset, B. Presence of genetic mutations, C. Rate of disease progression, D. Symptoms experienced Correct Option: B
Question 5: How does the degeneration of motor neurons in ALS affect the muscles? Options: A. The muscles become stronger and more rigid, B. The muscles waste away due to lack of regular cues, C. The muscles experience temporary paralysis, D. The muscles become inflamed Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is one prevailing idea about the cause of ALS? Options: A. Exposure to toxins and viruses, B. Genetic mutations in multiple genes, C. Misfolded proteins forming clumps inside motor neurons, D. Lifestyle and environmental factors Correct Option: C
Question 7: What factors contribute to the complexity of ALS? Options: A. Involvement of multiple genes and genetic mutations, B. Presence of inflammation in the brain and spinal cord, C. Defective immune cells and changed behavior of support cells, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 8: What can be said about the current state of ALS treatment? Options: A. There is a single, effective treatment for ALS, B. Current treatments can cure ALS, C. Researchers are developing new drugs, stem cell therapies, and gene therapies, D. There are no treatment options available for ALS Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the primary challenge in developing effective treatments for ALS? Options: A. Limited funding for research, B. Complexity of the disease and multiple factors involved, C. Lack of awareness about ALS, D. Limited number of people affected by ALS Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the potential outcome of further research and discovery in ALS? Options: A. Development of a single, definitive test for ALS, B. Identification of a single cause of ALS, C. Discovery of new treatments and potential cure for ALS, D. Reduced funding for ALS research Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (identifying alternative names for ALS), options (listing the alternative names), and content (ALS being referred to by multiple names). 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1963, a 21-year-old physicist 
named Stephen Hawking was diagnosed with a rare
neuromuscular disorder called amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, 
or ALS. Gradually, he lost the ability to walk, use his hands, move his face, and even swallow. But throughout it all,
he retained his incredible intellect, and in the more
than 50 years that followed, Hawking became one of history’s most 
accomplished and famous physicists. However, his condition went uncured and he passed away in 2018 
at the age of 76. Decades after his diagnosis, ALS still ranks as one 
of the most complex, mysterious, and devastating 
diseases to affect humankind. Also called motor neuron disease 
and Lou Gehrig’s Disease, ALS affects about two out of every
100,000 people worldwide. When a person has ALS, their motor neurons, the cells responsible for all voluntary 
muscle control in the body, lose function and die. No one knows exactly why
or how these cells die and that’s part of what 
makes ALS so hard to treat. In about 90% of cases, the disease arises suddenly, 
with no apparent cause. The remaining 10% of cases are hereditary, where a mother or father with ALS passes 
on a mutated gene to their child. The symptoms typically first appear 
after age 40. But in some rare cases, like Hawking’s,
ALS starts earlier in life. Hawking’s case was also a medical marvel 
because of how long he lived with ALS. After diagnosis, most people with 
the disease live between 2 to 5 years before ALS leads to respiratory problems 
that usually cause death. What wasn’t unusual in Hawking’s case
was that his ability to learn, think, and perceive with his senses 
remained intact. Most people with ALS do not experience
impaired cognition. With so much at stake 
for the 120,000 people who are diagnosed with ALS annually, curing the disease has become one of 
our most important scientific and medical challenges. Despite the many unknowns, we do have some insight into how ALS 
impacts the neuromuscular system. ALS affects two types of nerve cells 
called the upper and lower motor neurons. In a healthy body, 
the upper motor neurons, which sit in the brain’s cortex, transmit messages
from the brain to the lower motor neurons, situated in the spinal cord. Those neurons then transmit 
the message into muscle fibers, which contract or relax in response, resulting in motion. Every voluntary move we make occurs because of messages transmitted 
along this pathway. But when motor neurons degenerate in ALS, their ability to transfer 
messages is disrupted, and that vital signaling system 
is thrown into chaos. Without their regular cues, 
the muscles waste away. Precisely what makes 
the motor neurons degenerate is the prevailing 
mystery of ALS. In hereditary cases, parents pass genetic 
mutations on to their children. Even then, ALS involves multiple genes with multiple possible impacts 
on motor neurons, making the precise triggers
hard to pinpoint. When ALS arises sporadically,
the list of possible causes grows: toxins, viruses, lifestyle, or other environmental factors 
may all play roles. And because there are 
so many elements involved, there’s currently no single test that
can determine whether someone has ALS. Nevertheless, our hypotheses 
on the causes are developing. One prevailing idea is that certain
proteins inside the motor neurons aren’t folding correctly, and are instead forming clumps. The misfolded proteins and clumps 
may spread from cell to cell. This could be clogging up normal
cellular processes, like energy and protein production, 
which keep cells alive. We’ve also learned that along with 
motor neurons and muscle fibers, ALS could involve other
cell types. ALS patients typically have inflammation 
in their brains and spinal cords. Defective immune cells may also play 
a role in killing motor neurons. And ALS seems to change the
behavior of specific cells that provide support for neurons. These factors highlight 
the disease’s complexity, but they may also give us a fuller
understanding of how it works, opening up new avenues for treatment. And while that may be gradual,
we’re making progress all the time. We’re currently developing new drugs, new stem cell therapies 
to repair damaged cells, and new gene therapies 
to slow the advancement of the disease. With our growing arsenal of knowledge, we look forward to discoveries
that can change the future for people living with ALS.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: About how many people are diagnosed with ALS worldwide per year?
Options: A. About 30,000, B. About 100,000, C. About 120,000, D. About 1,000,000
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the rare neuromuscular disorder that Stephen Hawking was diagnosed with in 1963, which is also known by two other names? Options: A. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), B. Motor Neuron Disease, C. Lou Gehrig's Disease, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 2: What is the primary function of motor neurons in the human body? Options: A. To control involuntary muscle movements, B. To regulate body temperature, C. To transmit messages for voluntary muscle control, D. To produce hormones Correct Option: C
Question 3: According to the transcript, what is the typical expected lifespan of a person diagnosed with ALS after the onset of symptoms? Options: A. 10-15 years, B. 2-5 years, C. 5-10 years, D. 1-2 years Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary difference between hereditary and sporadic cases of ALS? Options: A. Age of onset, B. Presence of genetic mutations, C. Rate of disease progression, D. Symptoms experienced Correct Option: B
Question 5: How does the degeneration of motor neurons in ALS affect the muscles? Options: A. The muscles become stronger and more rigid, B. The muscles waste away due to lack of regular cues, C. The muscles experience temporary paralysis, D. The muscles become inflamed Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is one prevailing idea about the cause of ALS? Options: A. Exposure to toxins and viruses, B. Genetic mutations in multiple genes, C. Misfolded proteins forming clumps inside motor neurons, D. Lifestyle and environmental factors Correct Option: C
Question 7: What factors contribute to the complexity of ALS? Options: A. Involvement of multiple genes and genetic mutations, B. Presence of inflammation in the brain and spinal cord, C. Defective immune cells and changed behavior of support cells, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 8: What can be said about the current state of ALS treatment? Options: A. There is a single, effective treatment for ALS, B. Current treatments can cure ALS, C. Researchers are developing new drugs, stem cell therapies, and gene therapies, D. There are no treatment options available for ALS Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the primary challenge in developing effective treatments for ALS? Options: A. Limited funding for research, B. Complexity of the disease and multiple factors involved, C. Lack of awareness about ALS, D. Limited number of people affected by ALS Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the potential outcome of further research and discovery in ALS? Options: A. Development of a single, definitive test for ALS, B. Identification of a single cause of ALS, C. Discovery of new treatments and potential cure for ALS, D. Reduced funding for ALS research Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, based on the overall intent of the ground truth MCQ, which is to inquire about the prevalence or statistics of ALS, I would say that none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ.

However, if I had to choose one that is somewhat related to statistics or prevalence, I would say that Question 3 is the closest, but it's still not a match.

A more suitable answer would be to generate a new MCQ that directly matches the ground truth MCQ or to acknowledge that none of the existing generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to provide an index, I would say that there is no matching index, but if I had to choose one that is somewhat related, I would say:

Index: None (or 3, but with the caveat that it's not a direct match)

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1963, a 21-year-old physicist 
named Stephen Hawking was diagnosed with a rare
neuromuscular disorder called amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, 
or ALS. Gradually, he lost the ability to walk, use his hands, move his face, and even swallow. But throughout it all,
he retained his incredible intellect, and in the more
than 50 years that followed, Hawking became one of history’s most 
accomplished and famous physicists. However, his condition went uncured and he passed away in 2018 
at the age of 76. Decades after his diagnosis, ALS still ranks as one 
of the most complex, mysterious, and devastating 
diseases to affect humankind. Also called motor neuron disease 
and Lou Gehrig’s Disease, ALS affects about two out of every
100,000 people worldwide. When a person has ALS, their motor neurons, the cells responsible for all voluntary 
muscle control in the body, lose function and die. No one knows exactly why
or how these cells die and that’s part of what 
makes ALS so hard to treat. In about 90% of cases, the disease arises suddenly, 
with no apparent cause. The remaining 10% of cases are hereditary, where a mother or father with ALS passes 
on a mutated gene to their child. The symptoms typically first appear 
after age 40. But in some rare cases, like Hawking’s,
ALS starts earlier in life. Hawking’s case was also a medical marvel 
because of how long he lived with ALS. After diagnosis, most people with 
the disease live between 2 to 5 years before ALS leads to respiratory problems 
that usually cause death. What wasn’t unusual in Hawking’s case
was that his ability to learn, think, and perceive with his senses 
remained intact. Most people with ALS do not experience
impaired cognition. With so much at stake 
for the 120,000 people who are diagnosed with ALS annually, curing the disease has become one of 
our most important scientific and medical challenges. Despite the many unknowns, we do have some insight into how ALS 
impacts the neuromuscular system. ALS affects two types of nerve cells 
called the upper and lower motor neurons. In a healthy body, 
the upper motor neurons, which sit in the brain’s cortex, transmit messages
from the brain to the lower motor neurons, situated in the spinal cord. Those neurons then transmit 
the message into muscle fibers, which contract or relax in response, resulting in motion. Every voluntary move we make occurs because of messages transmitted 
along this pathway. But when motor neurons degenerate in ALS, their ability to transfer 
messages is disrupted, and that vital signaling system 
is thrown into chaos. Without their regular cues, 
the muscles waste away. Precisely what makes 
the motor neurons degenerate is the prevailing 
mystery of ALS. In hereditary cases, parents pass genetic 
mutations on to their children. Even then, ALS involves multiple genes with multiple possible impacts 
on motor neurons, making the precise triggers
hard to pinpoint. When ALS arises sporadically,
the list of possible causes grows: toxins, viruses, lifestyle, or other environmental factors 
may all play roles. And because there are 
so many elements involved, there’s currently no single test that
can determine whether someone has ALS. Nevertheless, our hypotheses 
on the causes are developing. One prevailing idea is that certain
proteins inside the motor neurons aren’t folding correctly, and are instead forming clumps. The misfolded proteins and clumps 
may spread from cell to cell. This could be clogging up normal
cellular processes, like energy and protein production, 
which keep cells alive. We’ve also learned that along with 
motor neurons and muscle fibers, ALS could involve other
cell types. ALS patients typically have inflammation 
in their brains and spinal cords. Defective immune cells may also play 
a role in killing motor neurons. And ALS seems to change the
behavior of specific cells that provide support for neurons. These factors highlight 
the disease’s complexity, but they may also give us a fuller
understanding of how it works, opening up new avenues for treatment. And while that may be gradual,
we’re making progress all the time. We’re currently developing new drugs, new stem cell therapies 
to repair damaged cells, and new gene therapies 
to slow the advancement of the disease. With our growing arsenal of knowledge, we look forward to discoveries
that can change the future for people living with ALS.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What percentage of ALS is not hereditary?
Options: A. About 10%, B. About 40%, C. About 50%, D. About 90%
Correct Option: D

**Transcript**:
In 1963, a 21-year-old physicist 
named Stephen Hawking was diagnosed with a rare
neuromuscular disorder called amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, 
or ALS. Gradually, he lost the ability to walk, use his hands, move his face, and even swallow. But throughout it all,
he retained his incredible intellect, and in the more
than 50 years that followed, Hawking became one of history’s most 
accomplished and famous physicists. However, his condition went uncured and he passed away in 2018 
at the age of 76. Decades after his diagnosis, ALS still ranks as one 
of the most complex, mysterious, and devastating 
diseases to affect humankind. Also called motor neuron disease 
and Lou Gehrig’s Disease, ALS affects about two out of every
100,000 people worldwide. When a person has ALS, their motor neurons, the cells responsible for all voluntary 
muscle control in the body, lose function and die. No one knows exactly why
or how these cells die and that’s part of what 
makes ALS so hard to treat. In about 90% of cases, the disease arises suddenly, 
with no apparent cause. The remaining 10% of cases are hereditary, where a mother or father with ALS passes 
on a mutated gene to their child. The symptoms typically first appear 
after age 40. But in some rare cases, like Hawking’s,
ALS starts earlier in life. Hawking’s case was also a medical marvel 
because of how long he lived with ALS. After diagnosis, most people with 
the disease live between 2 to 5 years before ALS leads to respiratory problems 
that usually cause death. What wasn’t unusual in Hawking’s case
was that his ability to learn, think, and perceive with his senses 
remained intact. Most people with ALS do not experience
impaired cognition. With so much at stake 
for the 120,000 people who are diagnosed with ALS annually, curing the disease has become one of 
our most important scientific and medical challenges. Despite the many unknowns, we do have some insight into how ALS 
impacts the neuromuscular system. ALS affects two types of nerve cells 
called the upper and lower motor neurons. In a healthy body, 
the upper motor neurons, which sit in the brain’s cortex, transmit messages
from the brain to the lower motor neurons, situated in the spinal cord. Those neurons then transmit 
the message into muscle fibers, which contract or relax in response, resulting in motion. Every voluntary move we make occurs because of messages transmitted 
along this pathway. But when motor neurons degenerate in ALS, their ability to transfer 
messages is disrupted, and that vital signaling system 
is thrown into chaos. Without their regular cues, 
the muscles waste away. Precisely what makes 
the motor neurons degenerate is the prevailing 
mystery of ALS. In hereditary cases, parents pass genetic 
mutations on to their children. Even then, ALS involves multiple genes with multiple possible impacts 
on motor neurons, making the precise triggers
hard to pinpoint. When ALS arises sporadically,
the list of possible causes grows: toxins, viruses, lifestyle, or other environmental factors 
may all play roles. And because there are 
so many elements involved, there’s currently no single test that
can determine whether someone has ALS. Nevertheless, our hypotheses 
on the causes are developing. One prevailing idea is that certain
proteins inside the motor neurons aren’t folding correctly, and are instead forming clumps. The misfolded proteins and clumps 
may spread from cell to cell. This could be clogging up normal
cellular processes, like energy and protein production, 
which keep cells alive. We’ve also learned that along with 
motor neurons and muscle fibers, ALS could involve other
cell types. ALS patients typically have inflammation 
in their brains and spinal cords. Defective immune cells may also play 
a role in killing motor neurons. And ALS seems to change the
behavior of specific cells that provide support for neurons. These factors highlight 
the disease’s complexity, but they may also give us a fuller
understanding of how it works, opening up new avenues for treatment. And while that may be gradual,
we’re making progress all the time. We’re currently developing new drugs, new stem cell therapies 
to repair damaged cells, and new gene therapies 
to slow the advancement of the disease. With our growing arsenal of knowledge, we look forward to discoveries
that can change the future for people living with ALS.

Correct Option: B

However, it's worth noting that there isn't a perfect match between the ground truth MCQ and any of the generated MCQs. But among the available options, Question 5 is the most similar.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On July 4, 2015, a NASA spacecraft called New Horizons 
was 5 billion kilometers away from Earth. It was only 10 days away from Pluto, 
after flying for 9.5 years, when it suddenly dropped out of contact. But let’s back up a little. As of 1989, mankind had successfully sent craft 
to every known planet in the solar system except one—Pluto. You may have heard that astronomers 
don’t consider Pluto or its brethren to be planets. However, most planetary 
scientists still do, which is why we're using 
that terminology here. There’s a limited amount 
we can learn about Pluto from Earth because it’s so far from us. Pluto, however, is a scientific goldmine. It’s located in a region 
called the Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, hundreds of thousands 
of ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets. This mysterious region holds clues 
to the formation of our solar system, and it was long, 
tantalizingly beyond our reach. Until New Horizons. Its objectives: explore Pluto, collect as much scientific 
data as possible, transmit it back to Earth, then explore farther out 
in the Kuiper Belt. To achieve this, the New Horizons team 
outfitted their craft with seven state-of-the-art 
scientific instruments. Those included Ralph, a set of cameras powerful enough to capture features the size 
of city blocks in Manhattan from tens of thousands of kilometers away. And REX, designed to use radio waves to measure Pluto’s atmospheric pressure 
and temperature. All of the onboard equipment had to be
built to be both reliable and lightweight because New Horizons had an
additional challenge; it had to reach its target 
as fast as possible. Why? Around 2020, Pluto will reach 
a point in its orbit where its atmosphere could freeze. And due to the tilt of its axis, more and more of Pluto’s surface 
is shrouded in darkness every year. Pluto completes a full orbit
once every 248 Earth years, so it would be a long wait 
for the next prime opportunity to visit. To see how New Horizons 
got to Pluto in time, let’s jump to its launch. Its three rocket stages accelerated 
New Horizons to such great speeds that it crossed the 400,000 kilometers 
to the moon in just nine hours. About a year later, 
the craft reached Jupiter and got what’s called a gravity assist. That’s where it flies close enough
to the gas giant to receive a gravitational
slingshot effect. New Horizons was then flying 
at around 50,000 kilometers per hour, as it would for the next eight years 
to cross the remaining gulf to Pluto. Going at such an astonishing speed meant that slowing down 
to get into orbit or land would’ve been impossible. That’s why New Horizons was on 
a flyby mission, where it would get just one chance to
scream by Pluto and make its observations. The flyby would have 
to be fully automated, since at that distance, any signals 
to guide it from Earth would take 4.5 hours to reach it. So the team loaded the ship’s computer 
with a series of thousands of commands, called the core load, that would begin to execute 
when the craft was 6.5 days from Pluto. But when New Horizons 
was just ten days out, disaster almost struck. Ground control lost contact 
with the spacecraft. After two nerve-wracking hours,
New Horizons came back online, but mission control discovered 
that its main computer had rebooted, losing the entire core load 
and other critical data. Without that, it would soon 
whizz by Pluto with virtually nothing 
to show for the mission. Alice Bowman, 
the mission’s Operations Manager, led a team for 72 sleepless hours 
to get the instructions loaded back into New Horizons in time. Without room for a single error,
she and her team pulled it off, and New Horizons began taking 
and broadcasting breathtaking images. Those observations have revealed 
a delightfully varied world, with ground fogs, high altitude hazes, possible clouds, canyons, towering mountains, faults, craters, polar caps, glaciers, apparent dune fields, suspected ice volcanoes, evidence for past flowing liquids, and more. One of the most exciting discoveries is the 1000-kilometer-wide
Sputnik Planitia glacier. Sputnik Planitia is mainly composed 
of slowly churning frozen nitrogen, and we’ve never seen anything 
like it in our solar system. The exploration of Pluto 
was a great success, but New Horizons isn’t done yet. On January 1, 2019, it’ll break its own record for 
furthest explored object when it visits a Kuiper Belt Object 
called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the sun another billion
kilometers farther away than Pluto. The world is holding its breath 
to see what it’ll find there.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where is Pluto located?
Options: A. The Kuiper Belt, B. The Prometheus Belt, C. The Andromeda Belt, D. The Odysseus Belt
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary objective of the New Horizons spacecraft? Options: A. To explore Mars and its moons, B. To explore Pluto, collect scientific data, and transmit it back to Earth, C. To study the Sun's corona, D. To search for life on Europa Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the name of the region in our solar system where Pluto is located, and what is unique about it? Options: A. The Kuiper Belt, home to many large planets, B. The Oort Cloud, a region with extreme temperatures, C. The Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets, D. The asteroid belt, a region with many rocky objects Correct Option: C
Question 3: Why did the New Horizons spacecraft have to reach Pluto as fast as possible? Options: A. Because Pluto's atmosphere was changing rapidly, B. Because Pluto's orbit was shifting due to Jupiter's gravitational pull, C. Because Pluto's atmosphere could freeze, and its surface would be shrouded in darkness, D. Because the spacecraft's fuel was limited Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is a gravity assist, and how did it help the New Horizons spacecraft? Options: A. A gravity assist is when a spacecraft uses its engines to accelerate, and it helped New Horizons reach Pluto faster, B. A gravity assist is when a spacecraft flies close to a planet to receive a gravitational slingshot effect, and it helped New Horizons change direction, C. A gravity assist is when a spacecraft uses the gravity of a planet to slow down, and it helped New Horizons enter Pluto's orbit, D. A gravity assist is when a spacecraft flies close to a planet to receive a gravitational slingshot effect, and it helped New Horizons increase its speed Correct Option: D
Question 5: Why was the New Horizons spacecraft unable to slow down and enter Pluto's orbit? Options: A. Because it was too heavy, B. Because it was traveling too fast, C. Because it didn't have enough fuel, D. Because Pluto's gravity was too weak Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was the core load, and why was it critical to the mission's success? Options: A. The core load was a series of commands that would guide the spacecraft during its flyby, and it was critical because it would ensure the spacecraft collected data, B. The core load was a set of instructions that would control the spacecraft's speed, and it was critical because it would prevent the spacecraft from crashing, C. The core load was a series of commands that would begin to execute when the craft was 6.5 days from Pluto, and it was critical because it would automate the flyby, D. The core load was a set of data that would be transmitted back to Earth, and it was critical because it would provide insights into Pluto's composition Correct Option: C
Question 7: What happened to the New Horizons spacecraft when it was just ten days away from Pluto, and how was the issue resolved? Options: A. The spacecraft experienced a power failure, and the issue was resolved by rebooting the system, B. The spacecraft lost contact with ground control, and the issue was resolved by reloading the core load, C. The spacecraft's main computer failed, and the issue was resolved by replacing it with a backup, D. The spacecraft's communication antenna was damaged, and the issue was resolved by using a backup antenna Correct Option: B
Question 8: What happened to the New Horizons spacecraft when it was just ten days away from Pluto, and how was the issue resolved? Options: A. The spacecraft experienced a power failure, and the issue was resolved by rebooting the system, B. The spacecraft's main computer rebooted, losing the core load, and the issue was resolved by reloading the core load, C. The spacecraft's main computer failed, and the issue was resolved by replacing it with a backup, D. The spacecraft's communication antenna was damaged, and the issue was resolved by using a backup antenna Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the Sputnik Planitia glacier, and what is unique about it? Options: A. The Sputnik Planitia glacier is a 1000-kilometer-wide glacier on Pluto composed of water ice, B. The Sputnik Planitia glacier is a 1000-kilometer-wide glacier on Pluto composed of slowly churning frozen nitrogen, C. The Sputnik Planitia glacier is a 1000-kilometer-wide glacier on Mars composed of dry ice, D. The Sputnik Planitia glacier is a 1000-kilometer-wide glacier on Europa composed of liquid water Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the next destination for the New Horizons spacecraft, and what is significant about it? Options: A. The next destination is a Kuiper Belt Object called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the Sun another billion kilometers farther away than Pluto, B. The next destination is a Kuiper Belt Object called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the Sun closer than Pluto, C. The next destination is a planet in the outer reaches of the solar system, D. The next destination is an asteroid in the asteroid belt Correct Option: A
Question 11: Evaluate the significance of the New Horizons mission in the context of space exploration. Which of the following statements best describes its impact? Options: A. The New Horizons mission was a minor achievement in space exploration, providing limited insights into Pluto's composition, B. The New Horizons mission was a significant achievement in space exploration, providing the first close-up images of Pluto and expanding our understanding of the Kuiper Belt, C. The New Horizons mission was a major breakthrough in space exploration, discovering life on Pluto and revolutionizing our understanding of the solar system, D. The New Horizons mission was a failure, failing to provide any significant insights into Pluto's composition or the Kuiper Belt Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question asks about the region in our solar system where Pluto is located and what is unique about it. The correct option, C, states that Pluto is located in the Kuiper Belt, which is home to many small planets, ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets. This matches the content and intent of the ground truth MCQ, which asks where Pluto is located and has the correct option A, "The Kuiper Belt". 

Although the options in Question 2 are not identical to those in the ground truth MCQ, the question content and correct answer are similar, making it the most closely matching generated MCQ. 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On July 4, 2015, a NASA spacecraft called New Horizons 
was 5 billion kilometers away from Earth. It was only 10 days away from Pluto, 
after flying for 9.5 years, when it suddenly dropped out of contact. But let’s back up a little. As of 1989, mankind had successfully sent craft 
to every known planet in the solar system except one—Pluto. You may have heard that astronomers 
don’t consider Pluto or its brethren to be planets. However, most planetary 
scientists still do, which is why we're using 
that terminology here. There’s a limited amount 
we can learn about Pluto from Earth because it’s so far from us. Pluto, however, is a scientific goldmine. It’s located in a region 
called the Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, hundreds of thousands 
of ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets. This mysterious region holds clues 
to the formation of our solar system, and it was long, 
tantalizingly beyond our reach. Until New Horizons. Its objectives: explore Pluto, collect as much scientific 
data as possible, transmit it back to Earth, then explore farther out 
in the Kuiper Belt. To achieve this, the New Horizons team 
outfitted their craft with seven state-of-the-art 
scientific instruments. Those included Ralph, a set of cameras powerful enough to capture features the size 
of city blocks in Manhattan from tens of thousands of kilometers away. And REX, designed to use radio waves to measure Pluto’s atmospheric pressure 
and temperature. All of the onboard equipment had to be
built to be both reliable and lightweight because New Horizons had an
additional challenge; it had to reach its target 
as fast as possible. Why? Around 2020, Pluto will reach 
a point in its orbit where its atmosphere could freeze. And due to the tilt of its axis, more and more of Pluto’s surface 
is shrouded in darkness every year. Pluto completes a full orbit
once every 248 Earth years, so it would be a long wait 
for the next prime opportunity to visit. To see how New Horizons 
got to Pluto in time, let’s jump to its launch. Its three rocket stages accelerated 
New Horizons to such great speeds that it crossed the 400,000 kilometers 
to the moon in just nine hours. About a year later, 
the craft reached Jupiter and got what’s called a gravity assist. That’s where it flies close enough
to the gas giant to receive a gravitational
slingshot effect. New Horizons was then flying 
at around 50,000 kilometers per hour, as it would for the next eight years 
to cross the remaining gulf to Pluto. Going at such an astonishing speed meant that slowing down 
to get into orbit or land would’ve been impossible. That’s why New Horizons was on 
a flyby mission, where it would get just one chance to
scream by Pluto and make its observations. The flyby would have 
to be fully automated, since at that distance, any signals 
to guide it from Earth would take 4.5 hours to reach it. So the team loaded the ship’s computer 
with a series of thousands of commands, called the core load, that would begin to execute 
when the craft was 6.5 days from Pluto. But when New Horizons 
was just ten days out, disaster almost struck. Ground control lost contact 
with the spacecraft. After two nerve-wracking hours,
New Horizons came back online, but mission control discovered 
that its main computer had rebooted, losing the entire core load 
and other critical data. Without that, it would soon 
whizz by Pluto with virtually nothing 
to show for the mission. Alice Bowman, 
the mission’s Operations Manager, led a team for 72 sleepless hours 
to get the instructions loaded back into New Horizons in time. Without room for a single error,
she and her team pulled it off, and New Horizons began taking 
and broadcasting breathtaking images. Those observations have revealed 
a delightfully varied world, with ground fogs, high altitude hazes, possible clouds, canyons, towering mountains, faults, craters, polar caps, glaciers, apparent dune fields, suspected ice volcanoes, evidence for past flowing liquids, and more. One of the most exciting discoveries is the 1000-kilometer-wide
Sputnik Planitia glacier. Sputnik Planitia is mainly composed 
of slowly churning frozen nitrogen, and we’ve never seen anything 
like it in our solar system. The exploration of Pluto 
was a great success, but New Horizons isn’t done yet. On January 1, 2019, it’ll break its own record for 
furthest explored object when it visits a Kuiper Belt Object 
called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the sun another billion
kilometers farther away than Pluto. The world is holding its breath 
to see what it’ll find there.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What were the objectives of New Horizons?
Options: A. To explore Pluto, B. To collect as much scientific data as possible and transmit it back, C. To explore farther out in the Kuiper Belt, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On July 4, 2015, a NASA spacecraft called New Horizons 
was 5 billion kilometers away from Earth. It was only 10 days away from Pluto, 
after flying for 9.5 years, when it suddenly dropped out of contact. But let’s back up a little. As of 1989, mankind had successfully sent craft 
to every known planet in the solar system except one—Pluto. You may have heard that astronomers 
don’t consider Pluto or its brethren to be planets. However, most planetary 
scientists still do, which is why we're using 
that terminology here. There’s a limited amount 
we can learn about Pluto from Earth because it’s so far from us. Pluto, however, is a scientific goldmine. It’s located in a region 
called the Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, hundreds of thousands 
of ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets. This mysterious region holds clues 
to the formation of our solar system, and it was long, 
tantalizingly beyond our reach. Until New Horizons. Its objectives: explore Pluto, collect as much scientific 
data as possible, transmit it back to Earth, then explore farther out 
in the Kuiper Belt. To achieve this, the New Horizons team 
outfitted their craft with seven state-of-the-art 
scientific instruments. Those included Ralph, a set of cameras powerful enough to capture features the size 
of city blocks in Manhattan from tens of thousands of kilometers away. And REX, designed to use radio waves to measure Pluto’s atmospheric pressure 
and temperature. All of the onboard equipment had to be
built to be both reliable and lightweight because New Horizons had an
additional challenge; it had to reach its target 
as fast as possible. Why? Around 2020, Pluto will reach 
a point in its orbit where its atmosphere could freeze. And due to the tilt of its axis, more and more of Pluto’s surface 
is shrouded in darkness every year. Pluto completes a full orbit
once every 248 Earth years, so it would be a long wait 
for the next prime opportunity to visit. To see how New Horizons 
got to Pluto in time, let’s jump to its launch. Its three rocket stages accelerated 
New Horizons to such great speeds that it crossed the 400,000 kilometers 
to the moon in just nine hours. About a year later, 
the craft reached Jupiter and got what’s called a gravity assist. That’s where it flies close enough
to the gas giant to receive a gravitational
slingshot effect. New Horizons was then flying 
at around 50,000 kilometers per hour, as it would for the next eight years 
to cross the remaining gulf to Pluto. Going at such an astonishing speed meant that slowing down 
to get into orbit or land would’ve been impossible. That’s why New Horizons was on 
a flyby mission, where it would get just one chance to
scream by Pluto and make its observations. The flyby would have 
to be fully automated, since at that distance, any signals 
to guide it from Earth would take 4.5 hours to reach it. So the team loaded the ship’s computer 
with a series of thousands of commands, called the core load, that would begin to execute 
when the craft was 6.5 days from Pluto. But when New Horizons 
was just ten days out, disaster almost struck. Ground control lost contact 
with the spacecraft. After two nerve-wracking hours,
New Horizons came back online, but mission control discovered 
that its main computer had rebooted, losing the entire core load 
and other critical data. Without that, it would soon 
whizz by Pluto with virtually nothing 
to show for the mission. Alice Bowman, 
the mission’s Operations Manager, led a team for 72 sleepless hours 
to get the instructions loaded back into New Horizons in time. Without room for a single error,
she and her team pulled it off, and New Horizons began taking 
and broadcasting breathtaking images. Those observations have revealed 
a delightfully varied world, with ground fogs, high altitude hazes, possible clouds, canyons, towering mountains, faults, craters, polar caps, glaciers, apparent dune fields, suspected ice volcanoes, evidence for past flowing liquids, and more. One of the most exciting discoveries is the 1000-kilometer-wide
Sputnik Planitia glacier. Sputnik Planitia is mainly composed 
of slowly churning frozen nitrogen, and we’ve never seen anything 
like it in our solar system. The exploration of Pluto 
was a great success, but New Horizons isn’t done yet. On January 1, 2019, it’ll break its own record for 
furthest explored object when it visits a Kuiper Belt Object 
called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the sun another billion
kilometers farther away than Pluto. The world is holding its breath 
to see what it’ll find there.

The Radio Science Experiment designed to test for signs of life on Pluto, D. The Radio Science Experiment designed to take photographs
Correct Option: B

Question 9: What is the Sputnik Planitia glacier, and what is unique about it? Options: A. The Sputnik Planitia glacier is a 1000-kilometer-wide glacier on Pluto composed of water ice, B. The Sputnik Planitia glacier is a 1000-kilometer-wide glacier on Pluto composed of slowly churning frozen nitrogen, C. The Sputnik Planitia glacier is a 1000-kilometer-wide glacier on Mars composed of dry ice, D. The Sputnik Planitia glacier is a 1000-kilometer-wide glacier on Europa composed of liquid water Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the next destination for the New Horizons spacecraft, and what is significant about it? Options: A. The next destination is a Kuiper Belt Object called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the Sun another billion kilometers farther away than Pluto, B. The next destination is a Kuiper Belt Object called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the Sun closer than Pluto, C. The next destination is a planet in the outer reaches of the solar system, D. The next destination is an asteroid in the asteroid belt Correct Option: A
Question 11: Evaluate the significance of the New Horizons mission in the context of space exploration. Which of the following statements best describes its impact? Options: A. The New Horizons mission was a minor achievement in space exploration, providing limited insights into Pluto's composition, B. The New Horizons mission was a significant achievement in space exploration, providing the first close-up images of Pluto and expanding our understanding of the Kuiper Belt, C. The New Horizons mission was a major breakthrough in space exploration, discovering life on Pluto and revolutionizing our understanding of the solar system, D. The New Horizons mission was a failure, failing to provide any significant insights into Pluto's composition or the Kuiper Belt Correct Option: B

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On July 4, 2015, a NASA spacecraft called New Horizons 
was 5 billion kilometers away from Earth. It was only 10 days away from Pluto, 
after flying for 9.5 years, when it suddenly dropped out of contact. But let’s back up a little. As of 1989, mankind had successfully sent craft 
to every known planet in the solar system except one—Pluto. You may have heard that astronomers 
don’t consider Pluto or its brethren to be planets. However, most planetary 
scientists still do, which is why we're using 
that terminology here. There’s a limited amount 
we can learn about Pluto from Earth because it’s so far from us. Pluto, however, is a scientific goldmine. It’s located in a region 
called the Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, hundreds of thousands 
of ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets. This mysterious region holds clues 
to the formation of our solar system, and it was long, 
tantalizingly beyond our reach. Until New Horizons. Its objectives: explore Pluto, collect as much scientific 
data as possible, transmit it back to Earth, then explore farther out 
in the Kuiper Belt. To achieve this, the New Horizons team 
outfitted their craft with seven state-of-the-art 
scientific instruments. Those included Ralph, a set of cameras powerful enough to capture features the size 
of city blocks in Manhattan from tens of thousands of kilometers away. And REX, designed to use radio waves to measure Pluto’s atmospheric pressure 
and temperature. All of the onboard equipment had to be
built to be both reliable and lightweight because New Horizons had an
additional challenge; it had to reach its target 
as fast as possible. Why? Around 2020, Pluto will reach 
a point in its orbit where its atmosphere could freeze. And due to the tilt of its axis, more and more of Pluto’s surface 
is shrouded in darkness every year. Pluto completes a full orbit
once every 248 Earth years, so it would be a long wait 
for the next prime opportunity to visit. To see how New Horizons 
got to Pluto in time, let’s jump to its launch. Its three rocket stages accelerated 
New Horizons to such great speeds that it crossed the 400,000 kilometers 
to the moon in just nine hours. About a year later, 
the craft reached Jupiter and got what’s called a gravity assist. That’s where it flies close enough
to the gas giant to receive a gravitational
slingshot effect. New Horizons was then flying 
at around 50,000 kilometers per hour, as it would for the next eight years 
to cross the remaining gulf to Pluto. Going at such an astonishing speed meant that slowing down 
to get into orbit or land would’ve been impossible. That’s why New Horizons was on 
a flyby mission, where it would get just one chance to
scream by Pluto and make its observations. The flyby would have 
to be fully automated, since at that distance, any signals 
to guide it from Earth would take 4.5 hours to reach it. So the team loaded the ship’s computer 
with a series of thousands of commands, called the core load, that would begin to execute 
when the craft was 6.5 days from Pluto. But when New Horizons 
was just ten days out, disaster almost struck. Ground control lost contact 
with the spacecraft. After two nerve-wracking hours,
New Horizons came back online, but mission control discovered 
that its main computer had rebooted, losing the entire core load 
and other critical data. Without that, it would soon 
whizz by Pluto with virtually nothing 
to show for the mission. Alice Bowman, 
the mission’s Operations Manager, led a team for 72 sleepless hours 
to get the instructions loaded back into New Horizons in time. Without room for a single error,
she and her team pulled it off, and New Horizons began taking 
and broadcasting breathtaking images. Those observations have revealed 
a delightfully varied world, with ground fogs, high altitude hazes, possible clouds, canyons, towering mountains, faults, craters, polar caps, glaciers, apparent dune fields, suspected ice volcanoes, evidence for past flowing liquids, and more. One of the most exciting discoveries is the 1000-kilometer-wide
Sputnik Planitia glacier. Sputnik Planitia is mainly composed 
of slowly churning frozen nitrogen, and we’ve never seen anything 
like it in our solar system. The exploration of Pluto 
was a great success, but New Horizons isn’t done yet. On January 1, 2019, it’ll break its own record for 
furthest explored object when it visits a Kuiper Belt Object 
called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the sun another billion
kilometers farther away than Pluto. The world is holding its breath 
to see what it’ll find there.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long does it take Pluto to complete a full orbit?
Options: A. 50 Earth years, B. 127 Earth years, C. 248 Earth years, D. 683 Earth years
Correct Option: C

Question 2: What is the name of the region in our solar system where Pluto is located, and what is unique about it? Options: A. The Kuiper Belt, home to many large planets, B. The Oort Cloud, a region with extreme temperatures, C. The Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets, D. Because the spacecraft's fuel was limited Correct Option: C

A gravity assist is when a spacecraft flies close to a planet to receive a gravitational slingshot effect, and it helped New Horizons change direction, C. A gravity assist is when a spacecraft uses the gravity of a planet to slow down, and it helped New Horizons enter Pluto's orbit, D. The spacecraft's communication antenna was damaged, and the issue was resolved by using a backup antenna Correct Option: B

The spacecraft experienced a power failure, and the issue was resolved by rebooting the system, B. **Transcript**:
On July 4, 2015, a NASA spacecraft called New Horizons 
was 5 billion kilometers away from Earth. It was only 10 days away from Pluto, 
after flying for 9.5 years, when it suddenly dropped out of contact. But let’s back up a little. As of 1989, mankind had successfully sent craft 
to every known planet in the solar system except one—Pluto. You may have heard that astronomers 
don’t consider Pluto or its brethren to be planets. However, most planetary 
scientists still do, which is why we're using 
that terminology here. There’s a limited amount 
we can learn about Pluto from Earth because it’s so far from us. Pluto, however, is a scientific goldmine. It’s located in a region 
called the Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, hundreds of thousands 
of ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets. This mysterious region holds clues 
to the formation of our solar system, and it was long, 
tantalizingly beyond our reach. Until New Horizons. Its objectives: explore Pluto, collect as much scientific 
data as possible, transmit it back to Earth, then explore farther out 
in the Kuiper Belt. To achieve this, the New Horizons team 
outfitted their craft with seven state-of-the-art 
scientific instruments. Those included Ralph, a set of cameras powerful enough to capture features the size 
of city blocks in Manhattan from tens of thousands of kilometers away. And REX, designed to use radio waves to measure Pluto’s atmospheric pressure 
and temperature. All of the onboard equipment had to be

as fast as possible. Why? Around 2020, Pluto will reach 
a point in its orbit where its atmosphere could freeze. And due to the tilt of its axis, more and more of Pluto’s surface 
is shrouded in darkness every year. Pluto completes a full orbit

to the gas giant to receive a gravitational
slingshot effect. New Horizons was then flying

and broadcasting breathtaking images. Those observations have revealed

Sputnik Planitia glacier. Sputnik Planitia is mainly composed 
of slowly churning frozen nitrogen, and we’ve never seen anything 
like it in our solar system. The exploration of Pluto 
was a great success, but New Horizons isn’t done yet. On January 1, 2019, it’ll break its own record for 
furthest explored object when it visits a Kuiper Belt Object 
called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the sun another billion
kilometers farther away than Pluto. The world is holding its breath 
to see what it’ll find there.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The finish line's in sight
and you put on an extra burst of speed. As your legs pick up the pace,
your breathing gets deeper, your heart pounds faster, and sweat pours over your skin. How does this substance
suddenly materialize and what exactly is its purpose? There are a number of scenarios
that can make us sweat: eating spicy foods, nervousness, and when we're sick. But exercise is probably the most familiar
and common. In that case, sweating happens 
as a response to movement triggered deep inside your cells. As you increase your pace,
your muscles work harder, increasing their demand for energy. A process called cellular respiration consumes glucose 
and oxygen to form ATP, the energy currency of the cell. Much of this process takes place
in structures called mitochondria. The more you move, the harder mitochondria work
to supply your body with energy. All this work comes at a cost, though. As the cells break down the ATP,
they release heat. The heat stimulates temperature sensors
throughout your body. Those receptors detect the excess heat
being produced by your muscle cells and communicate that information
to the hypothalamus, which regulates body temperature. The hypothalamus responds by sending signals out through 
the sympathetic nervous system to the sweat glands in your skin. These are distributed all over the body with especially high concentrations
on the palms of your hands, the soles of your feet, and on your head. When a sweat gland first receives
the signal, the fluid surrounding the cells
in its coiled base contains high amounts 
of sodium and chloride. The cells pump these ions
into a hollow tube that runs through the sweat gland. Then, because it's saltier inside
the tube than outside, water moves into the tube by osmosis. As what's called the primary secretion
builds up in the bottom of the tube, water pressure pushes it up
into the long straight part of the duct. Before it seeps onto the skin, cells lining the tube will reclaim
as much salt as possible so the process can continue. The water in sweat absorbs 
your body's heat energy and then evaporates off of you
when it reaches the surface, which in turn lowers your temperature. This process, 
known as evaporative cooling, was an important adaptation 
for our ancestors. This cooling effect isn't only helpful
during exercise. We sweat in many other scenarios, too. Eating particularly spicy food makes some
people sweat profusely from their faces. That happens because spices trigger
the same neural response in the brain that activates temperature receptors,
which usually respond to increased heat. Sweating is also part of 
the fight or flight response stimulated by stressful scenarios,
like asking someone on a date or interviewing for a job. This happens because adrenaline
stimulates muscle activity and causes blood vessels to widen, two responses that increase heat
and trigger the sweating response. And sweating also occurs 
when we get sick. When we're feverish,
we sweat because infections stimulate the hypothalamus 
to increase muscle activity, which in turn releases 
more energy as heat. That increases your overall temperature, a protective mechanism that makes your
body less habitable for infectious agents. Like with running, sweating helps
your body vent that heat. When the fever's over 
or you've won your race, your temperature receptors 
sense the decrease in heat and the hypothalamus brings 
your sweating response to an end. In some cases, like after a run, the hypothalamus also signals
to your body that you need to replenish the water
that you've oozed out. So, when you're pushing yourself
to reach that next goal, you can think of sweat as your body's
very own calibrator, enabling you to go that extra mile.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following scenarios will you not sweat?
Options: A. Exercise, B. Eating spicy food, C. Overhydrating, D. Nervousness
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary purpose of sweat in the human body? Options: A. To release excess salt, B. To regulate body temperature, C. To respond to spicy food, D. To increase energy levels Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following best describes the process by which sweat is produced in the body? Options: A. The hypothalamus sends signals to the sweat glands, which then pump sodium and chloride ions into a hollow tube, and water moves in by osmosis., B. The sweat glands produce sweat in response to increased heat, which is then released onto the skin., C. The mitochondria produce sweat as a byproduct of cellular respiration., D. The sympathetic nervous system stimulates the sweat glands to produce sweat without any involvement of the hypothalamus. Correct Option: A
Question 3: A person is running a marathon on a hot summer day. What would happen to their sweat production if they were to slow down and walk instead of run? Options: A. Their sweat production would increase to compensate for the heat., B. Their sweat production would decrease as their body temperature decreases., C. Their sweat production would remain the same, as it is not affected by their pace., D. Their sweat production would stop, as they are no longer exercising intensely. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the relationship between the hypothalamus and sweat production in the body? Options: A. The hypothalamus stimulates the sweat glands directly to produce sweat., B. The hypothalamus regulates body temperature, which in turn affects sweat production., C. The hypothalamus has no role in sweat production., D. The hypothalamus inhibits sweat production in response to increased heat. Correct Option: B
Question 5: Compare and contrast the sweating response to exercise and the sweating response to eating spicy food. Options: A. Both responses are triggered by increased heat and involve the hypothalamus, but the response to exercise is more intense., B. The response to exercise is triggered by increased heat, while the response to eating spicy food is triggered by a neural response in the brain that simulates increased heat., C. The response to exercise involves the sympathetic nervous system, while the response to eating spicy food involves the parasympathetic nervous system., D. The response to exercise is a voluntary response, while the response to eating spicy food is an involuntary response. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the function of the coiled base of the sweat gland? Options: A. To pump sodium and chloride ions into the hollow tube, B. To reclaim salt from the primary secretion, C. To regulate body temperature, D. To filter waste products from the sweat Correct Option: A
Question 7: How does the process of evaporative cooling help to regulate body temperature? Options: A. By releasing excess heat into the environment, B. By absorbing heat energy from the body and evaporating it off the skin, C. By increasing blood flow to the skin, D. By decreasing sweat production Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the relationship between sweat production and fever? Options: A. Sweat production increases in response to fever to help vent excess heat., B. Sweat production decreases in response to fever to conserve energy., C. Sweat production is not affected by fever., D. Sweat production causes fever. Correct Option: A
Question 9: What would be an effective way to test the effect of exercise intensity on sweat production? Options: A. Have participants exercise at different intensities while measuring their sweat production and body temperature., B. Have participants exercise at the same intensity while measuring their sweat production and body temperature., C. Have participants sit at rest while measuring their sweat production and body temperature., D. Have participants exercise in different environmental conditions while measuring their sweat production and body temperature. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the role of sweat in enabling athletes to perform at a high level? Options: A. Sweat helps to regulate body temperature and maintain homeostasis during exercise., B. Sweat is only a byproduct of exercise and has no functional role., C. Sweat helps to regulate body temperature but is not essential for exercise performance., D. Sweat is the primary factor that enables athletes to perform at a high level. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 5 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

However, since Question 5 does not match the exact intent of the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify a scenario where sweating does not occur, I re-evaluated the options.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The finish line's in sight
and you put on an extra burst of speed. As your legs pick up the pace,
your breathing gets deeper, your heart pounds faster, and sweat pours over your skin. How does this substance
suddenly materialize and what exactly is its purpose? There are a number of scenarios
that can make us sweat: eating spicy foods, nervousness, and when we're sick. But exercise is probably the most familiar
and common. In that case, sweating happens 
as a response to movement triggered deep inside your cells. As you increase your pace,
your muscles work harder, increasing their demand for energy. A process called cellular respiration consumes glucose 
and oxygen to form ATP, the energy currency of the cell. Much of this process takes place
in structures called mitochondria. The more you move, the harder mitochondria work
to supply your body with energy. All this work comes at a cost, though. As the cells break down the ATP,
they release heat. The heat stimulates temperature sensors
throughout your body. Those receptors detect the excess heat
being produced by your muscle cells and communicate that information
to the hypothalamus, which regulates body temperature. The hypothalamus responds by sending signals out through 
the sympathetic nervous system to the sweat glands in your skin. These are distributed all over the body with especially high concentrations
on the palms of your hands, the soles of your feet, and on your head. When a sweat gland first receives
the signal, the fluid surrounding the cells
in its coiled base contains high amounts 
of sodium and chloride. The cells pump these ions
into a hollow tube that runs through the sweat gland. Then, because it's saltier inside
the tube than outside, water moves into the tube by osmosis. As what's called the primary secretion
builds up in the bottom of the tube, water pressure pushes it up
into the long straight part of the duct. Before it seeps onto the skin, cells lining the tube will reclaim
as much salt as possible so the process can continue. The water in sweat absorbs 
your body's heat energy and then evaporates off of you
when it reaches the surface, which in turn lowers your temperature. This process, 
known as evaporative cooling, was an important adaptation 
for our ancestors. This cooling effect isn't only helpful
during exercise. We sweat in many other scenarios, too. Eating particularly spicy food makes some
people sweat profusely from their faces. That happens because spices trigger
the same neural response in the brain that activates temperature receptors,
which usually respond to increased heat. Sweating is also part of 
the fight or flight response stimulated by stressful scenarios,
like asking someone on a date or interviewing for a job. This happens because adrenaline
stimulates muscle activity and causes blood vessels to widen, two responses that increase heat
and trigger the sweating response. And sweating also occurs 
when we get sick. When we're feverish,
we sweat because infections stimulate the hypothalamus 
to increase muscle activity, which in turn releases 
more energy as heat. That increases your overall temperature, a protective mechanism that makes your
body less habitable for infectious agents. Like with running, sweating helps
your body vent that heat. When the fever's over 
or you've won your race, your temperature receptors 
sense the decrease in heat and the hypothalamus brings 
your sweating response to an end. In some cases, like after a run, the hypothalamus also signals
to your body that you need to replenish the water
that you've oozed out. So, when you're pushing yourself
to reach that next goal, you can think of sweat as your body's
very own calibrator, enabling you to go that extra mile.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the source of your body’s temperature?
Options: A. Digestion of food, B. The breakdown of ATP to do work in cells, C. Friction when your muscle fibers move against each other, D. The burning of fat for energy
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary purpose of sweat in the human body? Options: A. To release excess salt, B. To regulate body temperature, C. To respond to spicy food, D. To increase energy levels Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following best describes the process by which sweat is produced in the body? Options: A. The hypothalamus sends signals to the sweat glands, which then pump sodium and chloride ions into a hollow tube, and water moves in by osmosis., B. The sweat glands produce sweat in response to increased heat, which is then released onto the skin., C. The mitochondria produce sweat as a byproduct of cellular respiration., D. The sympathetic nervous system stimulates the sweat glands to produce sweat without any involvement of the hypothalamus. Correct Option: A
Question 3: A person is running a marathon on a hot summer day. What would happen to their sweat production if they were to slow down and walk instead of run? Options: A. Their sweat production would increase to compensate for the heat., B. Their sweat production would decrease as their body temperature decreases., C. Their sweat production would remain the same, as it is not affected by their pace., D. Their sweat production would stop, as they are no longer exercising intensely. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the relationship between the hypothalamus and sweat production in the body? Options: A. The hypothalamus stimulates the sweat glands directly to produce sweat., B. The hypothalamus regulates body temperature, which in turn affects sweat production., C. The hypothalamus has no role in sweat production., D. The hypothalamus inhibits sweat production in response to increased heat. Correct Option: B
Question 5: Compare and contrast the sweating response to exercise and the sweating response to eating spicy food. Options: A. Both responses are triggered by increased heat and involve the hypothalamus, but the response to exercise is more intense., B. The response to exercise is triggered by increased heat, while the response to eating spicy food is triggered by a neural response in the brain that simulates increased heat., C. The response to exercise involves the sympathetic nervous system, while the response to eating spicy food involves the parasympathetic nervous system., D. The response to exercise is a voluntary response, while the response to eating spicy food is an involuntary response. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the function of the coiled base of the sweat gland? Options: A. To pump sodium and chloride ions into the hollow tube, B. To reclaim salt from the primary secretion, C. To regulate body temperature, D. To filter waste products from the sweat Correct Option: A
Question 7: How does the process of evaporative cooling help to regulate body temperature? Options: A. By releasing excess heat into the environment, B. By absorbing heat energy from the body and evaporating it off the skin, C. By increasing blood flow to the skin, D. By decreasing sweat production Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the relationship between sweat production and fever? Options: A. Sweat production increases in response to fever to help vent excess heat., B. Sweat production decreases in response to fever to conserve energy., C. Sweat production is not affected by fever., D. Sweat production causes fever. Correct Option: A
Question 9: What would be an effective way to test the effect of exercise intensity on sweat production? Options: A. Have participants exercise at different intensities while measuring their sweat production and body temperature., B. Have participants exercise at the same intensity while measuring their sweat production and body temperature., C. Have participants sit at rest while measuring their sweat production and body temperature., D. Have participants exercise in different environmental conditions while measuring their sweat production and body temperature. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the role of sweat in enabling athletes to perform at a high level? Options: A. Sweat helps to regulate body temperature and maintain homeostasis during exercise., B. Sweat is only a byproduct of exercise and has no functional role., C. Sweat helps to regulate body temperature but is not essential for exercise performance., D. Sweat is the primary factor that enables athletes to perform at a high level. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7: How does the process of evaporative cooling help to regulate body temperature? is not the most similar, however a more similar question would be one that involves the source of body heat.

A more similar question to the ground truth MCQ would be one that involves the source of body heat, which in this case is Question 2, but only the part "The mitochondria produce sweat as a byproduct of cellular respiration" is relevant to the ground truth MCQ.

However among the provided options the most similar question would be Question 4: What is the relationship between the hypothalamus and sweat production in the body? this question does not directly address the source of body heat but it does address the regulation of body temperature which is related to the source of body heat.

But if we were to choose the most similar question it would be Question 2, because it does address the cellular process which is the source of body heat.

So the index of the most similar generated MCQ would be 2.
